stem: A 78-year-old client is admitted for extreme dizziness. She takes metoprolol 50 mg and digoxin 0.125 mg daily. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Symptomatic bradycardia in an elderly patient.
Background: History of atrial fibrillation and hypertension. Stable medications for 2 years.
Assessment: Heart rate is 38 bpm. Client reports, 'Everything looks like there is a green tint on it.'
Recommendation: Immediate evaluation of digoxin level.

tabs.title: Polypharmacy & Rhythm Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
EKG Rhythm2nd Degree Heart Block (Type II)Critically slow (38 bpm)
Digoxin Level2.8 ng/mLToxic (> 2.0 ng/mL)
Serum Potassium3.4 mEq/L (Low)Potentiates digoxin effect
Serum Creatinine2.2 mg/dLRenal impairment (Clearing slow)

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 88/52 mmHg, HR 38 bpm, RR 18 breaths/min, T 98.2°F (36.8°C). SpO2 93% on room air.

actionOptions.text: Withhold both the digoxin and the metoprolol
Notify the provider and prepare for potential digoxin immune Fab (Digibind) administration
Encourage the client to drink a large glass of water to drop the metoprolol level
Place the client in an upright high-Fowler's position

parameterOptions.text: Continuous EKG rhythm and heart rate monitoring
Presence of visual disturbances (yellow/green halos) and nausea
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: The most likely condition is hypokalemia-aggravated digoxin toxicity (c2). While metoprolol (beta-blocker) also slows the heart rate, the green-tinted vision (xanthopsia) and the elevated digoxin level (2.8 ng/mL) confirm digoxin toxicity. The low potassium (3.4 mEq/L) increases the heart's sensitivity to digoxin's toxic effects. The nurse should withhold both digoxin and metoprolol (a1) and prepare for the administration of digoxin immune Fab (Digibind) (a2). Key parameters to monitor include continuous EKG rhythm and heart rate (p1) and the presence of visual disturbances and nausea (p2).
clinicalPearls: Digoxin + beta-blockers = synergistic bradycardia. This combination can significantly decrease heart rate.
Green/yellow tint (xanthopsia) is a specific indicator of digoxin toxicity.
Hypokalemia is a common factor that can precipitate digoxin toxicity in patients on a stable dose.

questionTrap.trap: Attributing the bradycardia (38 bpm) solely to the beta-blocker.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Consider the client's report of visual disturbances (green tint) and the elevated digoxin level. Beta-blockers do not cause visual disturbances.

mnemonic.title: DIG-TOX
mnemonic.expansion: D-Disturbed vision (yellow/green halos), I-Increased digoxin level, G-GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting), TO-Toxic effects, X-eXtreme bradycardia
